If airlines can choose to bump passengers with zero-fare tickets first due to the proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket, doesn't that resemble a system where wealthier passengers are prioritized over those with lower socioeconomic status?

If airlines should prioritize compensation for bumped passengers based on the average ticket price, then doesn't this encourage them to overprice tickets for those passengers who actually pay the lowest fares?

atraveller_82_1.input:
atraveller: "Although we always travel with epipens in case our fiveryearold peanut & tree nut allergic child needs them,
I think having some on board is a good idea,
as long as crew are trained in the proper usage.
Moreover, I think the crew need training on how to respectfully treat people with allergies or disabilities.
Since our son was diagnosed with the allergy one year ago, we have travelled several times on multiple carriers and have found the foreign carriers to be far less worrisome for those with nut allergies.
In fact, none of the foreign carriers we used during that time even served nuts in economy."

cqs.cq: If crew are trained in the proper usage of epipens but not in how to respectfully treat people with allergies or disabilities, what effect might this have on the overall experience of passengers with special needs?
Do you have evidence that the foreign carriers you've praised for their allergy accommodations are indeed training their crew on how to respectfully treat people with allergies or disabilities?
If airlines can be held responsible for the well-being of passengers with allergies, would they not also be responsible for accommodating passengers with disabilities?

If crew training is considered crucial for handling allergy and disability cases, why isn't the same level of training prioritized for airline staff in the US, which seems to have been less accommodating for passengers with nut allergies compared to foreign carriers?

atraveller_82_2.input:
atraveller: "Our only trouble came with Delta.
On flights to and from Atlanta to El Salvador, I requested a nutfree buffer zone as listed as an option on the Delta website.
This request was not observed on either flight,
and I when mentioned it to the cabin crew on one segment, they began taking back the nuts from the passengers around us, pointing out that they couldn't have it because "that little boy is allergic."
This made us very uncomfortable, but at least the other passengers were polite about it.
I find it amazing that people get so incensed about "their rights" to have nuts being infringed upon.
I have a feeling that these are the same people who would be the first to complain when a plane has to make an emergency landing when a nutallergic passenger goes into anaphylaxis."

cqs.cq: What if prioritizing the rights of a single nut-allergic passenger causes the entire flight to become uncomfortable for everyone else?

Do you think it is reasonable for airline staff to prioritize the safety of a single passenger over the convenience of others when there are clearly designated options for special meal requests available?
If cabin crew accommodate a nut-allergic child, why should their accommodations be conditional upon a child's existence?
If cabin crew prioritize accommodating a passenger's allergy over other passengers' rights to have nuts, shouldn't airlines prioritize accommodating passengers' rights over their own interests?

cd38_220_1.input:
cd38: "As someone who carries an epipen for beestings,
I understand that allergies can be serious and life threatening.
Banning airlines from serving peanuts inflight seems reasonable;
several posts mention the risk inherent in many people opening bags of peanuts at one time
(which can easily happen when snacks are served)
throwing a large amount of dust in the air,
which could be enough to trigger an allergy in severely allergic people.
However, banning people from carrying on their own snacks does seem to violate their rights,
to eliminate what seems like an extremely small risk to allergysufferers.
Nuts are a healthy, portable form of protein,
and cannot be replaced by pretzels.
No, being hungry or not eating protein won't kill someone;
but, I'm a vegetarian,
and  I fly constantly, often on longhaul international flights, but mainly between the east and west coasts,"

cqs.cq: What if the ban on peanuts on flights causes more harm than good by severely limiting the dietary options of passengers while potentially triggering only a small risk to those with allergies?
Do you consider the rights of individuals with allergies to outweigh the convenience of airline passengers when it comes to in-flight snack policies?

If banning airlines from serving peanuts inflight is deemed a reasonable safety measure to protect severely allergic passengers, wouldn't prohibiting passengers from carrying their own snacks also be a reasonable measure to protect the rights of those passengers?
If banning peanuts on flights seems reasonable to protect severely allergic people, then why does allowing individuals to carry their own snacks not also seem reasonable to protect their rights?

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Would the risks of a peanut allergy incident be significantly reduced if airlines were to stop serving peanuts, but still allow passengers to bring their own peanuts on board?

Do you believe that the minimal risk of peanut-related incidents on flights is sufficient justification for airlines to completely restrict passengers from bringing and consuming peanuts, rather than just not serving them on board?

If airlines can restrict what passengers may eat to minimize the risk of a peanut-related incident, why can't they also restrict passengers from bringing their own food, thereby reducing the risk of a peanut-related incident to almost zero?

Should the airline's decision to serve cashews on a flight where a nut allergy exists override the risk of a potentially life-threatening reaction to a passenger with the passenger's choice to eat peanuts they brought on board?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: What if DOT's objective of eliminating all bumping is taken literally, then why should there be a cap on compensation that allows airlines to continue bumping passengers in exchange for a lesser financial penalty?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that treating passengers as economic units devoid of humanity is an effective way to eliminate bumping in the airline industry?

If airlines are to treat passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, shouldn't the financial penalty for bumping be strong enough to eliminate it entirely, rather than merely keep it at an "acceptable" level?

If DOT's objective is to eliminate all bumping, then why would the airline be allowed to compensate passengers with only 100% of their ticket price, rather than a more substantial amount that could fully cover their expenses?

citizen-s_176.input:
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: If airlines are incentivized to bump passengers with zeroprice tickets first, wouldn't this cause them to prioritize those passengers over those with average-priced tickets?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that passengers with zero-price tickets should be compensated at the average cash ticket price for that service class on that flight?

If airlines are required to compensate passengers with zeroprice tickets at the average cash ticket price, wouldn't that create a precedent for treating passengers with higher-priced tickets as first-class when it comes to bumping?

If airlines are required to compensate bumped passengers with the average ticket price, doesn't that incentivize them to prioritize passengers with higher-priced tickets over those with zero-price tickets?

darawayne_121.input:
darawayne: "The price of fuel doesn't change while I am trying to book a flight.
Maybe airlines should only be allowed to change prices once a week, or once a day, always at midnight, or something like that.
It is extremely frustrating to try to buy a ticket and have availability and/or price change while you are pushing the "Buy" button."

cqs.cq: Would the lack of a standardized, uniform pricing schedule cause airlines to make more transparent and predictable decisions about their ticket pricing?
Do you have any evidence from airline industry experts that suggests the current dynamic pricing system, where prices can fluctuate in real-time, is detrimental to consumers rather than beneficial?
If airlines are allowed to adjust prices while customers are attempting to book a flight, would that not be similar to a store changing prices while a customer is checking out?

If airlines are free to adjust prices during the booking process, why should consumers be expected to pay the higher price if they're forced to book quickly, potentially losing out on cheaper options?

darawayne_182.input:
darawayne: "This is the same as bumping and should be compensated (punishment to the airlines) as such.
It is not just the five hours, though that is bad enough; it is all the other inconveniences, arriving late at night, having to cancel engagements, having to call a cab for a long ride vs bus transportation, and a myriad other inconveniences for which the airlines in their hubris currently accepts no responsibility."
 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If the airlines' practice of changing flight schedules without compensation causes significant inconveniences for passengers like yourself, then do you think they should be held accountable and required to fully reimburse passengers for these inconveniences?

Do you have any scientific evidence or industry data that supports the notion that airlines are solely responsible for compensating passengers for flight schedule changes without any regard for the passengers' prior arrangements or travel plans?

If airlines can charge passengers $150 to change their flight schedules after booking, why can't they be held accountable for the significant inconveniences and losses that result from their own schedule changes?

If passengers are entitled to compensation and consideration when the airline changes flight schedules after booking, why should the airlines not be held accountable for the significant inconveniences caused by such changes?

JDwyer_17.input:
JDwyer: "Size of aircraft should be irrelevant.
I was trapped on a very small (approx 21 passengers) aircraft, in the hot summer sun, for hours, with no ventilation.
Outrageous!
Being cooked in a small tin can is no better than being cooked in a big one!"

cqs.cq: What if the aircraft's size causes passengers to suffer heat-related illnesses, which might lead to a higher risk of in-flight emergencies?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the size of an aircraft has a significant impact on passenger comfort in the absence of ventilation?
If the discomfort of being trapped in a small aircraft is comparable to being cooked in a tin can, would the comfort of being on a larger aircraft be comparable to being cooked in a bigger tin can?
If the size of the aircraft is irrelevant to the passenger's experience, then shouldn't we also consider the size of a prison cell to be irrelevant to the prisoner's experience?

JJMurray_140.input:
JJMurray: "Make the compensation exactly what it is intended to be...
the cost (or double the cost) of the ticket, no cap since there is no cap on how much you may pay for that ticket.
Frequent flyer miles should simply be refunded
or a double amount refunded
in the same way as a cash ticket is handled.
Keep this simple and it will work much better.
On smaller flights, use the same rules.
Again, keep it simple.
Best way to give passengers information is to post it online, on a legible sign in the gate area, and in print large enough to read on tickets.
If people won't take the time to read at least one of those sources then they only have themselves to blame for not knowing about this."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency in ticket policies causes passengers to be uninformed about their compensation options?

Do you have any evidence that passengers who don't read the information posted online, on a legible sign in the gate area, and in print on their tickets are entirely responsible for their own lack of knowledge about airline policies?

If passengers are expected to take the time to read legible signs, large print tickets, and online information to understand their rights, why should airlines not provide clear, easily accessible, and understandable information about the refund policies for frequent flyer miles?
If passengers are expected to be informed about the rules regarding frequent flyer miles, shouldn't airlines also be held accountable for clearly communicating the same information?

JJMurray_143.input:
JJMurray: "No, no, no!
If you have an allergy to peanuts and you know you have it then take your own precautions.
If I decide to bring a bag of peanuts onboard an airplane and am then told I'm in a "peanut free zone" or something like that, then my rights have been trampled as have the rights of everyone in that zone.
Request peanut free services from the airlines for yourself,
but do not force those restrictions on the rest of the flying public.
I have no problem with the airline offering peanut free foods, etc.
but it should be an option that people can select
not a requirement for everyone else to abide by.
What's next?
Can I have all perfume banned from an airplane or have people wearing them banned?
How about deodorants, hair sprays, any product with latex in it?
It is not a "right" if you have to impose that behavior on others for yourself."

cqs.cq: If airlines offering peanut-free services can be seen as an optional choice, can requiring all passengers to adhere to a "peanut-free zone" also be viewed as a similar optional choice?
Do you think your personal preference for a peanut-free environment on an airplane should be a universal requirement rather than an optional choice for those who need it?

If having a peanut allergy is a legitimate reason to request special accommodations, would requiring airlines to ban all perfume, deodorants, or hair sprays also be a legitimate reason to impose on others?
If airlines can offer peanut-free options without requiring everyone to abide by them, then can they also offer perfume-free options without requiring everyone to abstain from perfume?

JJMurray_166.input:
JJMurray: "I have no problem with airlines developing their own policies vice a mandated government requirement
but whatever those policies are they need to be easy to find, easy to read and understandable by your "average" person before someone books and pays for a flight.
If you want to regulate this then insist that all policies related to overbooking, rebooking, rerouting, basically any changes to the originally contracted flight must be made available in a format that is easily accessible and understandable to the general public."

cqs.cq: Would requiring airlines to make their policies easily accessible and understandable to the general public cause a decrease in confusion among passengers, thus affecting their overall travel experience?

Do you have a scientific study or expert opinion that supports the claim that the average person's understanding of airline policies is a critical factor in determining consumer satisfaction, rather than the airline's ability to communicate policies effectively?

If airlines are required to make their policies easily accessible and understandable to the general public, wouldn't the same standard apply to the complex and often convoluted language used in government regulations?
If consumers have the right to easily access and understand airline policies, then shouldn't the government's regulations be easily accessible and understandable as well?

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts from airplanes cause a domino effect, leading to a chain of demands to ban other items, thereby increasing the complexity of airline regulations and potentially outweighing the benefits of the original safety measure?

Do you have any evidence that shows the removal of peanuts from aircraft, combined with repeated standard cleanings, is a more effective safety measure than the complete ban of peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter from airlines?

If the airline industry can't guarantee the complete removal of peanuts and peanut products from planes, why would a blanket ban on peanuts be more effective than allowing airlines to take a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets?

If airlines can effectively clean their fleets to minimize peanut exposure, why would a blanket ban on peanuts and peanut-containing items be necessary when it may not fully address the risk of airborne particles and crumbs?

JL_15.input:
JL: "The consumer credit industry is very highly regulated
The regulations have been over-hauled three times in the last decade"

cqs.cq: Does the industry's current high level of regulation cause it to be less prone to catastrophic failures like the ones experienced in the past?
Do you have any evidence that the three times of over-hauling regulations in the consumer credit industry resulted in any significant improvements?
If the consumer credit industry is highly regulated, wouldn't its financial practices and institutions also be held accountable for past and ongoing injustices?
If the regulations have been over-hauled three times in the last decade, does this suggest that the consumer credit industry is not adequately regulated despite the claims of high regulation?

JL_3.input:
JL: "Oh, I don’t think that’s true at all
You don’t pay an interest rate
The interest rate varies by the amount of the charge for the credit but also the time over which you repay it
So if you borrow some money from me, and you pay it back very quickly, the interest rate will be much higher than if you pay it back over a long period
But the amount it costs you is exactly the same"

cqs.cq: Does the varying interest rate cause the amount you pay to be higher when you repay the credit over a long period compared to paying it back quickly?
Do you have any evidence from a reputable financial institution that supports your claim that the interest rate varies directly by the repayment period rather than the borrower's credit score?
If a borrower pays back a loan quickly, why would the interest rate being higher not be analogous to a worker earning more for working more quickly?
If the interest rate is directly tied to the time of repayment, then why does the borrower not benefit from paying back the loan as quickly as possible?

JL_5.input:
JL: "Because they’re very short-term loans
if you borrowed £200 from me, and in 30 days time you pay back £250, the interest rate on that is 1,413.01%
It sounds horrendous
...
But if you pay me back the same amount of money in six months time the interest rate is only 57.3%.
And if you take a year to pay it back it goes down"

cqs.cq: Does the arbitrary reduction in interest rate based on the borrower's repayment timeframe effectively cause the lenders to prioritize short-term loans over long-term loans?
Does your explanation about the variable interest rates on short-term loans accurately reflect the typical practices of legitimate lending institutions?
If a £200 loan with a 1,413.01% interest rate over 30 days is considered "horrendous," wouldn't a £200 loan with a 57.3% interest rate over a year also be considered predatory?
If the interest rate can be that high for short-term loans, why should the government allow banks to charge even higher interest rates and still be considered a responsible financial institution?

JW_41.input:
JW: "It’s only since the state intervened that people have been uninterested in which bank they put their money in
In the old days of early capitalism, bankers were famously prudent people. And they went to great lengths to advertise how prudent they were.
This stopped not because of the big bang, which liberalised banking, which is what everybody thinks.
It stopped because of government guarantees to depositors."

cqs.cq: What if the government guarantees to depositors caused the prudent behavior of bankers to disappear?

Do you have any evidence from historical records or economic analyses that suggest prudent banking practices were indeed a hallmark of pre-liberalization banking, rather than just a claim based on anecdotal accounts?

If prudent bankers were once so careful with their financial decisions, how does the fact that government guarantees now protect depositors not also imply that the state's intervention has made banking less about prudent decisions?
If prudent bankers were indeed prudent in the past, does this imply that government guarantees undermined their prudence?

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.
They can't have it both ways."

cqs.cq: What if requiring airlines to provide timely notification of delays causes flyers to delay their trips, which in turn may lead to a decrease in airline efficiency and an increase in passenger frustration?

Do you have any evidence or data suggesting that requiring airlines to notify passengers of delays within 30 minutes of becoming aware of the issue significantly reduces the number of passengers who experience unnecessary delays or airport waiting times?
If airlines can't predict with certainty the exact timing of weather holds or maintenance issues, how can passengers reasonably expect them to notify delays within a specific time frame?

If airlines are required to provide timely notice of delays, wouldn't that then create unrealistic expectations for flyers who may end up waiting unnecessarily, ultimately leading to missed flights and further inconvenience?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: What if the current pay structure causes flight crew members to feel undervalued and underpaid, which might affect their job satisfaction and overall performance?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that most crew members would be "balking" at a pay structure that pays them for less than the actual time worked, considering the industry standard is to compensate for the time spent on the ground?
If pilots and flight attendants are paid for actual flight time, why would the ground delay time that affects their overall work hours not also be compensated?
If JetJock's proposed pay structure is more equitable, why do airlines still pay flight crew members less for actual flight time than for scheduled time?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

cqs.cq: What if the 3-hour limit rule causes more cancellations due to ATC or weather, then how would the airlines' ability to provide adequate amenities and accommodations to passengers in those situations be affected?
Do you have a scientific study or industry data that supports the claim that the 3-hour rule would cause more damage to air travel than occasional ground delays due to ATC, weather, or VIP movement?

If airlines are required to provide meal and hotel compensation for flights canceled due to ground delays beyond their control, would they also be required to provide compensation for flights canceled due to exceeding the 3 hour limit?

If the airline's new 3-hour rule causes cancellations and the company is not providing adequate compensation to passengers, then shouldn't the airline also be held responsible for the inconvenience and losses incurred by the passengers?

KHenrickson_172.input:
KHenrickson: "The notification isn't so much a problem at most airports.
The electronic boards are usually updated minute by minute.
The problem is that the airlines will say "Flight 100, delayed till 7:00pm." then "Flight 100, delayed till 7:05pm".  And so on and so forth.
They're notifying everyone...with completely useless information.
Forcing them to do so more frequently isn't going to fix a thing.
Forcing them to come up with an accurate estimate is what is needed."

cqs.cq: What if the minute-by-minute updates of the electronic boards cause passengers to become unnecessarily anxious and stressed, affecting their overall travel experience?
Do you have any evidence that suggests the frequent updates of flight information, rather than the accuracy of the estimates, significantly improves passenger satisfaction at airports?

If airlines are required to notify passengers about minute-by-minute delays, would it not be more efficient to provide accurate and reliable information rather than continuously updating the boards with minor adjustments?
If the airline's minute-by-minute updates provide no useful information, then why do we need to force them to update the boards so frequently?

MP_22.input:
MP: "Well, you say the banks are the lenders
there are lots of other people who are lenders too
I mean everyone who puts money into a bank, or a building society, is putting it there so that the bank can lend it on
I mean you just heard Simon Rose say
there’s been 100 billion pounds transfer from savers to borrowers
So if you're going to raise your banner for anybody who’s doing badly in this situation, I would have thought you might have raised it for savers, in the first instance"

cqs.cq: What if the banks are the lenders who are actually transferring funds from savers to borrowers, does that not cause a lack of consideration for the savers' interests in the current discussion?

Can you explain why you're defending the banks' actions as lenders when they're actually just intermediaries between savers and borrowers, rather than taking a more nuanced view of the entire lending process?
If the MP believes savers should be prioritized over borrowers, wouldn't that imply that the banks' primary role is to serve savers, rather than lenders?
If everyone who puts money into a bank is a lender, then shouldn't the MP be advocating for savers rather than the banks, who are actually the lenders in this scenario?

MP_48.input:
MP: "	I think it’s very interesting that capitalism is coming under such a lot of attack here
And I don’t say that’s inappropriate
But we haven’t yet attacked democracy
I mean one of the things that strikes me about this is that when you have incumbent governments, and they see that consumer credit boom mushrooming and mushrooming, what do they do?
They don’t want to stop it
They don’t want to stop it, because they want voters.
They want voters who feel artificially rich
because voters who feel artificially rich will probably vote for the incumbent"

cqs.cq: If voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for the incumbent, does this create a cause for the incumbent governments to prioritize economic growth over other policy priorities?
Do you believe that the desire for voter loyalty is a more significant driver of incumbent government actions than a genuine concern for economic stability?

If politicians are more interested in maintaining consumer credit booms to win votes from artificially rich citizens, why would they not prioritize addressing systemic issues that perpetuate economic inequality?
If voters who feel artificially rich are indeed a desirable asset for incumbent governments, then does that imply that democracy is fundamentally transactional rather than a democratic institution?

MR_TELEVOID__178.input:
MR: "Maybe you're just the only one who gives a shit about their hair"
 < this message is answering to > 
XxEnder: "Am I the only one who noticed that Bernie combed his hair"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that Bernie's hair being combed influence the likelihood that XxEnder is the only one who noticed it?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that personal grooming habits are a unique characteristic of a single individual?

Wouldn't XxEnder's comment about Bernie's hair be an example of a white person pointing out a white person's hairstyle, highlighting the double standard of scrutinizing and commenting on the hair of people of color?
If you think XxEnder's comment is a legitimate observation, does that imply you're acknowledging the significance of Bernie's hair?

MT_10.input:
MT: "we know from lots and lots of research, you know this, that people aren’t very good at understanding financial products
And they're easily seduced into acting, in the short-term, in ways which aren’t very good for them in the long-term
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?"

cqs.cq: Does the exploitation of consumers' financial literacy weaknesses by the industry demonstrate a cause that leads to its own long-term profitability?

Do you have any evidence from the history of the financial services industry that demonstrates a commitment to exploiting consumer weaknesses is a deliberate and long-term strategy rather than a short-term marketing tactic?

Does the history of the financial services industry, which prioritizes short-term gains over long-term customer well-being, not mirror the broader societal issue of prioritizing short-term economic benefits over long-term social justice?

Doesn't the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck, then why should we trust that it will change its ways and prioritize consumers' long-term interests?

MT_40.input:
MT: "I don’t think you just said the opposite of them was neutral
So if they're virtues, doesn’t that imply that the opposite of thrift and prudence is immoral?
But, hold on
Isn’t it simply the case that buying a cup of coffee is something which is substantially less demanding than working up a long-term interest rate?
Therefore isn’t it a reasonable thing for the state to intervene in those cases
because the knowledge is bounded?"

cqs.cq: Does the assumption that virtues are the opposite of thrifty and prudent behaviors imply a moral obligation for the state to intervene in everyday choices like buying a cup of coffee?
Do you have a philosophical source that supports the idea that the state should intervene in economic matters solely based on the notion of virtue and vice?
If virtues like thrift and prudence are considered moral, doesn't that imply that their opposites, such as profligacy and recklessness, would also be immoral?
If virtues are indeed desirable, does that imply that their opposites, such as excess and recklessness, are also undesirable?

Melanie_64.input:
Melanie: "Well the State has taken a moral position
that position was non-judgmentalism
and terrible harm it’s done
It’s created a lot of victims who now need help themselves, and who sometimes go on to create other victims through crime
 I think they do need help
but that help should be very carefully calibrated, to restore the capacity for independence and personal responsibility"

cqs.cq: Does the State's non-judgmental approach cause a lack of accountability among those who commit crimes, ultimately affecting the effectiveness of rehabilitation efforts?
Do you consider the State's non-judgmentalism stance as an expert opinion that warrants rehabilitation programs for perpetrators rather than solely focusing on victim support?
Would a State that has enabled the perpetuation of harm through non-judgmentalism be expected to provide the most effective means to break the cycle of victimization?
If the State has taken a moral position of non-judgmentalism, does that not undermine the need for accountability and justice in cases where its policies have caused harm?

Mpogoda_184.input:
Mpogoda: "As a frequent traveler, I would welcome the rule requiring 24 hour refundability of fares + all fees.
Additionally, there should be a certain window,
say, 3 days prior to flying where you should be able to cancel your flight without penalty and receive a refund or at least the ability to change your itinerary without fee.
As I always say to all who will listen,
the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;
and lastly, being treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane."

cqs.cq: What if airlines' poor customer treatment and inconvenient policies cause travelers to lose trust in their services, thereby affecting their loyalty and willingness to book flights?
Do you have any evidence that airlines are significantly more profitable than any other industry despite treating customers with disdain and making their products inconvenient to use?
If airline companies can charge exorbitant fees for changing itineraries, why should they not also be required to offer 24-hour refundability of fares without any fees?

If airlines can afford to make their business model so inconvenient for customers, why can't they also afford to provide a 24-hour refundability of fares and fees, as well as a window for cancellations and itinerary changes without penalty?

MrFordization__82.input:
MrFordization: "Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat
Maybe he just knows more than you"

cqs.cq: Does the classification of global warming as a national security threat by the Pentagon imply that Mr. Ford believes it will cause significant damage to the country's infrastructure and economy?
Do you have any evidence or scientific sources that support the claim that Mr. Ford's classification of global warming as a national security threat is more accurate than other classifications?

If the Pentagon considers global warming a national security threat, would that not imply that environmental degradation is a threat to the country's very foundation, similar to how war and terrorism are?
If global warming is indeed a national security threat, why would the Pentagon not prioritize addressing it as a matter of military preparedness rather than a mere environmental concern?

Mulder_112.input:
Mulder: "Your argument is a strawman.
Nobody is advocating funerals;
you're just trying to deflect attention away from the issue,
which is that there is no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers.
And there is no scientific evidence to support your argument.
You can't even cite the studies you claim exist,
because they don't exist.
The only mean spirited people are those like yourself, who want to trample the rights of the majority for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people.
This has nothing to do with the founding of the U.S. at all."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of scientific evidence to support the argument about peanut allergy risk causes the dismissal of concerns about the rights of peanut allergy sufferers?
Do you have any scientific sources that support your claim that the rights of the majority should be trampled for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people?
If the argument that peanut allergy sufferers pose no risk is considered valid, would that not make the argument that the rights of the majority are being trampled by a small group equally valid?
If your argument is a strawman, does that imply you're avoiding the actual issue of the lack of scientific evidence supporting the claim that peanuts pose a significant risk to the general public?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: Does the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut exposure on an airplane outweigh the inconvenience of forgoing snacks for passengers with severe food allergies?

Do you have any evidence or scientific studies that support the claim that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil on an airplane is so high that it justifies an outright ban on serving peanuts on flights?

If a peanut allergy is a legitimate concern that can potentially result in death, why would the airline industry not be required to take more proactive measures to accommodate passengers with such allergies, rather than simply relying on passengers to take responsibility for their own safety?
If you're so concerned about your child's safety, why can't you find a way to desensitize him to peanut allergies, rather than relying solely on others to accommodate your fears?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: Is the advocacy of serving peanuts on airplanes a cause for the alleged compulsion to consume peanuts in this context, or is it merely a misguided and hyperbolic argument?
Do you think your zealous stance on peanuts is an accurate representation of the actual issue, or a manifestation of your own compulsive behavior?

Is it possible that the analogies between the concerns over peanut consumption and tobacco smoking, and the concerns over driving and car accidents, are being used to justify the same level of regulatory intervention?
Is it really possible that your argument about peanuts is a clever deflection from addressing the real issue, which is the fact that you're equating a minor risk with a public health menace?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people don’t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isn’t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: Does the incentivisation of saving in South Korea through economic policies not inadvertently create a system where the wealthy are more likely to benefit from debt forgiveness?
Do you think that prioritizing economic incentives for certain behaviors, such as saving, can be morally equivalent to writing off debt for those who need it most?

If incentivizing certain types of behaviour to maintain economic stability is seen as acceptable in South Korea, wouldn't incentivizing certain types of behaviour to maintain social stability, such as providing relief to those most in need, be similarly justified?
If South Korea incentivised saving through economic policies, why doesn't the current economic system incentivise debt relief for those who most need it?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If the airlines are allowed to discriminate on the basis of weight, do they have a cause to justify the increased charge for passengers like you who are charged more due to their weight?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that passengers' weights are a significant enough factor to justify discriminatory airline policies without regulatory concerns?
If airlines can discriminate on the basis of weight without facing regulatory action, why should they not be able to charge passengers based on their weight without facing regulatory action?

If the 250lb man's weight is not a factor in the airline's decision to charge him more, then why should the weight of the person who only checks a bag be a factor in the airline's decision to charge him more?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of personal space on flights causes passengers to develop deep vein thrombosis or other health issues, then shouldn't airlines be held responsible for addressing this health concern?
Do you consider the airline's decision to prioritize charging for carry-on pet fees over providing adequate personal space a reflection of DOT's priorities?
If airlines prioritize charging exorbitant fees for carrying pets onboard, shouldn't they also address and prioritize providing adequate space for passengers to exercise and prevent health issues?
If seat size and configuration are considered a health issue, then why do airlines not prioritize passenger space as a matter of public health and safety?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: If the presence of peanuts on an airline flight causes an allergic reaction in a passenger, would it be a more effective solution to ban peanuts entirely rather than requiring passengers to request a peanut-free flight?
Do you think it's reasonable to expect airlines to provide a completely peanut-free environment when there are already existing accommodations and protocols in place?
If airline staff can ensure peanuts are removed from the floor and between seats, why can't they also remove other allergenic foods from the environment?
If airlines can be so accommodating by removing peanuts from flights, why can't they be more proactive in preventing the spread of peanuts, especially when passengers have made specific requests?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: Will removing peanuts from planes cause a significant decrease in peanut-related allergic reactions among passengers?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms the severity of peanut-related reactions warrants removal of peanuts from planes over other potential in-flight hazards?

If peanuts are removed from planes due to the potential risks of airborne particles, crumbs, and residue, should other potential allergens, like shellfish or dairy, also be removed for similar reasons?
If peanuts pose such significant health risks, why should airlines continue to offer them as an in-flight snack option when safer alternatives are readily available?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any cleaning standards or requirements causes the allergy to manifest and affect passengers' health, potentially resulting in severe reactions?
Do you think that relying on airlines' "good faith effort" at cleaning their fleets would be a sufficient measure to ensure the safety of passengers with severe allergies?

If standard cleaning without further peanut exposure would be sufficient to minimize the risk of an allergic reaction, would the lack of EpiPens on planes not already pose a risk to passengers with severe allergies?

If the rule requires airlines to implement thorough cleaning procedures to minimize peanut exposure, should they not also be held accountable for the cost of providing EpiPens or other medications to passengers with severe allergies?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: What if the practice of separating fees that are part of a ticket fee causes ticket buyers to misinterpret the actual cost of the ticket?
Do you have a clear definition of what you mean by "variable fees" and how it would be accurately reflected in a ticket pricing structure?
If ticket fees are variable, why should they not be allowed to fluctuate based on the specific components of the ticket, rather than being fixed and potentially misleading?
If Qubbin's proposal to limit variable fees is intended to protect consumers, why does he still support the idea of listing separate components of a ticket fee?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy were insufficient, causing his allergic reaction to occur despite their attempts to mitigate the risk?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy were sufficient to prevent his allergic reaction on the return trip?
If airlines can accommodate and take necessary precautions for a child's severe peanut allergy, why can't they do the same for passengers with other severe food allergies?

If airlines took such extensive precautions to accommodate a peanut allergy, why did they not take similar measures to prevent a peanut-related reaction on the return trip, despite the passenger's previous experience with a similar issue?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts from airline flights actually cause a significant reduction in the number of severe peanut allergy reactions on planes?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that banning peanuts from airline flights would be a more effective solution to ensuring the safety of passengers with severe peanut allergies than other measures such as labeling peanuts as a potential allergen or providing epipen injections?
If peanut allergies can pose a significant risk to passengers, why should other potential allergens on flights, such as peanuts' residue, not also warrant similar safety measures?
If banning peanuts on flights would save lives, then why should we prioritize the convenience of passengers who don't have peanut allergies over the safety of those who do?

Sithsaber__198.input:
Sithsaber: "Have you been to high school
It's shit"
 < this message is answering to > 
g: "high school is high school, college is college"

cqs.cq: Does having attended high school cause someone to have a less nuanced understanding of the differences between high school and college?
Do you consider your opinion about high school being "just high school" to be based on personal experience or expert opinion?
If high school is considered a foundational educational institution, would it not be comparable to college in terms of its fundamental purpose and impact on one's life?
If high school is indeed high school, then how can you equate it to "shit" if it's supposed to be a place of learning and growth?

SofieM_128.input:
SofieM: "Keep in mind that you wouldn't be able to get out of the plane if it were in the air, either.
I think deplaning is a bit extreme,
because it could throw an already imbalanced flight schedule out of whack, and might delay flights even further or lead to cancellation.
I sat on a tarmac in London for five hours earlier this year, but I'd rather wait it out than hop off the plane and miss an opportunity to take off.
However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: Would deplaning cause the flight schedule to become even more imbalanced and lead to more cancellations?
Do you think deplaning should be an option for passengers when flights are significantly delayed, considering the potential impact on the overall flight schedule?
If airlines can update passengers on flight delays, why can't passengers update themselves on flight delays?
If deplaning can indeed throw a flight schedule out of balance, why would it not cause a more significant disruption to the entire airline industry?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that airlines, like Southwest, are offering low fares and benefiting from customer demand for flight status notifications contradict your claim that both profits and passengers suffer in the current state of air transit affairs?
Do you have any evidence from the proposed rule or your own experience that suggests airlines are not currently prioritizing customer satisfaction despite offering low fares?

If airlines are able to offer affordable fares and meet customer demands by providing timely flight information, wouldn't that suggest that the current state of air transit affairs is not detrimental to both passengers and profits?

If airlines can indeed benefit from offering timely and accurate flight information, why does the proposed rule still seem to imply that DOT should be responsible for providing this information, rather than relying on airlines' customer service plans?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Would blanket policies on travel restrictions for minors cause a reduction in airline options and choices for parents, ultimately affecting their ability to make informed decisions about travel arrangements?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that parents know their children better than airlines do regarding their ability to handle travel?

If SofieM's reasoning about parents being better suited to decide whether their children can fly alone is applied to other areas, would this not imply that individuals with unique circumstances should have more freedom to make their own choices rather than having a one-size-fits-all policy?
If blanket policies are beneficial in other areas, why would they be counterproductive in this context where parents are better equipped to make decisions about their children's travel?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: What if the deletion of the emails could cause a cover-up of her involvement in a scandal to affect her public image?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms the claim that women deleting emails is a criminal act that warrants no negotiation?
Would Trump's refusal to negotiate and his demand for Clinton to release her emails imply that he's attempting to distract from his own accountability?
If Trump says it's not negotiable, does that imply that the emails are too sensitive to be released?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: What if allowing the airborne dust of nuts on planes to cause an allergic reaction affects the safety and well-being of passengers with nut allergies?
Do you think it's reasonable for airlines to prioritize the comfort of passengers with nut allergies over the convenience of those who can simply avoid eating nuts?

If passengers with peanut allergies can be forced to take medication and risk severe reactions just from being near peanuts, why should airlines not take proactive measures to prevent the presence of peanuts on planes?
If the airline industry can't effectively enforce a 'nut-free' zone, why can't they take more comprehensive measures to ensure passenger safety by completely banning nuts on planes?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: If the airlines are not responsible for enforcing a 'nut free' flight, then why should they be responsible for enforcing a 'nut free' environment for passengers with severe nut allergies?

Do you have a scientific study or expert opinion that supports the claim that passengers should be completely prohibited from bringing or eating nuts on flights, while allowing others to eat their own food freely?
If airlines can prohibit the serving of nuts on flights, why would they not have the authority to prohibit passengers from bringing and eating their own nuts?
If airlines are responsible for ensuring passengers' safety, shouldn't they take proactive measures to prevent the presence of nuts on flights rather than simply allowing passengers to bring them?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: Would the mandatory option of cash payment, as proposed, be effective in incentivizing airlines to limit overbooking without unfairly penalizing certain travelers?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that an auction system, as proposed by Julian Simon, would be more effective in incentivizing airlines to limit overbooking than the current compensation limits?
If airlines are required to compensate passengers for being bumped, why should they not be incentivized to increase the proposed compensation limits to provide a more equitable outcome for travelers?

If the Wall Street Journal's proposed auction system, which rewards bumped passengers with a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat, is so compelling, why do the proposed compensation limits in the current system remain too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' practice of overbooking flights and auctioning seats leads to involuntary denials of boarding, would this cause a decrease in customer satisfaction and increase in airline accountability?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that involuntary denied boarding would more accurately price the delay through an auction, rather than simply having airlines overbook and deny passengers?

Would forcing airlines to auction off seats like commodities also make them more accountable for the consequences of overbooking, rather than merely requiring them to compensate passengers involuntarily denied boarding?

If airlines can auction off seats to price delay and make passengers involuntarily denied boarding, then why can't they auction off the right to overbook flights, thus making passengers involuntarily denied boarding, in order to optimize their financial results?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."
